overview_of_class: This course entails designing and carrying out a local fieldwork project through a variety of exploratory ethnographic methods. The aims are to provide students with experience for future research, exposure to varied methods, confidence for being creative with research methods, and a solid basis for evaluating research in general. In collaboration with a partner, students will devise a local fieldwork project on a topic that can lend itself to the methods at hand: participant observation, taking field notes, open ended interviews, commentaries on texts, writing and analyzing surveys, etc. The project should build on and develop a theoretical question relevant to anthropology. Each week will entail some reading and a methods assignment that you can tailor to your own project. Class time will be devoted to comparing methods as well as problems encountered during the week. The last assignment will be a write-up of the project in a short paper along with a class presentation. Anthropology majors & minors only.
name: Ethnographic Methods and Analysis

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: SeminarParticipants work in teams of two to conduct a field project designed to answer a specific question about a topic of students' choice.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Based on the conduct of a field project and class participation.
Each week will entail a short ethnographic field activity whose writeup will be given a pass or no-pass. Students will have a chance to revise any no-pass weekly grade. Those who successfully pass all weeks will receive an A; those with one weekly assignment not passed a B, and so on.
